III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section Rule 126. The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
Description administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff
on duty to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency’s program statement and to
provide for the continual needs, protection, and supervision of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation - Facility believes a youth should be on one-to-one supervision but
due to MDHHS not approving the funding of the one-to-one
payments there has been inconsistency of the one-to-one staffing
being provided.
- Concerns overall on the supervision being performed by staff
due to staff always being on their cell phones.
- Concern that a youth went AWOL during the community outing
due to lack of supervision of the staff on the outing with the youth.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 1/11/2024. She
reported receiving the information from an anonymous source who
refused to release any identifying information. Complainant
reported the facility is struggling with services to Youth A because
of Youth A’s disruptive behaviors. The one-to-one supervision for
Youth A has been discontinued by both the facility and the
referring county. Youth A struggled with the direct supervision and
became more dysregulated, so it was ended. Complainant also
reported staff are not allowed to use their cell phones during the
time they are working, and the cell phones are to be locked up.
This was instituted because staff were using their cell phones
during work hours. Complainant provided a copy of the incident
report involving Youth B going AWOL.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported Youth A has been in the program for the
past year and completed all of the requirements. MDHHS has
been aware of this situation and not presented an appropriate
replacement yet. Youth A has regressed and struggles to regulate
her emotions because of the uncertainty of Youth A’s future
placement or lack of placement. The one-to-one was discontinued
because Youth A struggled with the extra attention and staff are
now following a safety plan which appears to be working for Youth
A. The one-to-one was ended in November 2023. She reported
the phone use by staff has been addressed and new guidelines
have been discussed during team meetings. These team meeting
2

notes will be provided. The staff are not to use their phones for
personal use when in the milieu and supervising youth and
Administrator 1 also reported not observing staff using their
phones in the milieu. She reported knowing Youth B AWOLed and
stated Youth B had no history of AWOL ideation or risk that the
program was aware of. Youth B was described as being very
compliant up to the time of the AWOL.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported Youth A is not on one-to-one status and
is not presenting as needing one-to-one supervision. Administrator
2 also reported MDHHS is not supporting one-to-one supervision
for Youth A and that the clinical team supports the level of
supervision (safety plan with normal supervision) Youth A is
currently on. In regard to the cell phone allegations, Administrator
2 reported this has been discussed in team meetings and she will
provide the minutes of those meetings. She has informed staff
they are not to use their phones for personal issues when in the
milieu or supervising youth. Staff are allowed to take their phones
with them when taking youth off site but still not to use them for
personal issues. Administrator 2 was on personal leave at the time
of Youth B going AWOL and had no information to provide.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported the same as Administrator 2 in regard to
Youth A needing and receiving one-to-one supervision. She also
reported staff are not to use their phones for personal issues in
the milieu but in the past staff would use their phones to
communicate if something was occurring with a youth and they
inform other staff of the issue. They would text so the youth were
not privileged to the communication. Now, staff are to find other
ways to communicate without the use of the phone. She had no
information about Youth B’s AWOL because she was not present
nor working that day.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She gave a similar report about the one-to-one
supervision of Youth A. Youth A was on one-to-one in the past but
no longer needed such supervision. That level of supervision was
discontinued because Youth A no longer needed it not because of
any funding issues. The supervision was never funded by
MDHHS. Supervisor 1 also reported about a couple of months
ago, staff were told not to use their phones in the milieu and the
staff have been following this direction since then. She reported
staff use to text between themselves when it related to suspicious
behaviors but not longer do and will talk before or at the end of the
3

shift. If it is something that needs to be discussed immediately,
staff will keep supervision but stand outside of youth hearing them
to speak to each other. Supervisor 1 had no information about the
AWOL with Youth B because she was not present nor working
that day.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported Youth A was originally placed on one-to-
one supervision to help Youth A feel more secure. However,
Youth A reported feeling very restrictive and stifled with this level
of supervision. Youth A did not present with any self-harming
behaviors, and it was clinically decided to stop the one-to-one
after a meeting with Youth A’s worker. Supervisor 2 also reported
there was never a funding issue and the decision to place Youth A
on one-to-one was the clinical team’s decision as was the reason
to remove that level of supervision. In regard to the issue of cell
phone use in the milieu, Supervisor 2 reported staff are not to use
their phones in the milieu and then only for safety or if information
is needed outside of the milieu. Supervisor 2 had no information
about Youth B’s AWOL because she was not present nor working
that day.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. Therapist reported Youth A did not have an assigned
one-to-one supervision level until a meeting with the MDHHS
worker. The decision to place Youth A on that level of supervision
was the result of an incident when Youth A was attacked by
another youth (this incident was dismissed as a special
investigation). A clinical decision with the MDHHS Worker
resulted in Youth A being taken off one-to-one supervision and all
staff were informed of this decision. Therapist reported personal
phones are not to be used in the milieu, but the supervisor is
allowed to use a personal phone for emergencies. Staff are not to
have their phone visible in the milieu and need to lock the phone
up. This information was provided during team meetings and has
been effective for a couple of months. Therapist had no
information on Youth B going AWOL but never heard it was
because of a lack of supervision.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported Youth A was not on a one-to-one
supervision level and is on a safety plan to avoid incidents. Staff 1
never believed Youth A needed that level of supervision. Staff 1
reported staff’s personal phone must not be seen in the milieu and
placed in the office or off the unit. Staff are not to make personal
calls and only use the phone outside of the milieu for
4

communication between staff by texting. Staff 1 also reported
working when Youth B went AWOL and received a phone call
from the Staff 5 and Staff 6 who were supervising the outing. She
was given the same report that is documented in the Incident
Report outlining the AWOL. She had no concerns about the
supervision provided by staff. Staff 1’s only recommendation to
the staff supervising the outing was they should have been on the
ice with the youth during the skating time.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported feeling safe at the facility and has several
staff that she is comfortable speaking with when struggling with
something. These identified staff include Therapist who is very
helpful. Youth A believes she is not receiving help in finding new
placement and wants to move to independent living as soon as
possible. She believes staff are provided the appropriate level of
supervision for her and other youth.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported Youth A is not the youth on one-to-one
status and is supervised appropriately. She identified Youth F as
the youth on one-to-one supervision and believes Youth F
received one-to-one supervision “most of the time” but because of
staff shortages at times and on outings Youth F is not always
getting one-to-one. Staff 4 reported her example for this belief is
when there is an outing involving three staff to six youth and views
this as one staff to two youth even when their ratio is one staff to
three youth. She also reported a belief that normally the facility
would send four staff with six youth. In regard to personal cell
phone use, Staff 4 reported in a couple of team meetings in the
past the facility tried to find a solution to staff using their personal
cell phones while working. Staff 4 also reported being the
individual who brought this issue to administration’s attention.
Staff 4 believes the administration is working on this issue and has
made progress by limiting the use of personal phones in the
milieu. Staff 4 based her belief on this concern because “staff
have their own kids, and they need to pay attention to our kids”.
Staff 4 had no information about Youth B’s AWOL.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported being on the outing in which Youth B
went AWOL and said Staff 5 and Staff 6 were not really
supervising the youth during the outing because both were not on
the ice with the youth. Youth C also reported there were “lots of
girls who looked like Youth B” at the rink and it was very crowded.
Youth C reported Staff 5, and Staff 6 made a diligent effort to find
5

Youth B when it was discovered Youth B was missing. Youth C
reported feeling safe and taken care of at the facility.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported being one of the youths on the outing in
which Youth B went AWOL. She stated the skating rink was
crowded and after the buzzer sounded to clear the rink, everyone
lost sight of Youth B in the crowd. She reported hearing from
another youth (unable to identify who) that Youth B was planning
on going AWOL if given the chance but is unsure if this statement
was true. Youth D also reported Staff 5 and Staff 6 were watching
the youth skate and only lost sight of Youth B when Youth B
became mixed into a large crowd. Youth D reported feeling safe in
the program and that the program is really helping her make
changes.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/16/2024. She reported being a youth on the outing in which
Youth B went AWOL. She stated, “crazy how she got away with it”
because staff were watching us. She also reported Youth B took
advantage of the crowd and snuck out of the building. She
reported feeling safe at the facility and that the program is very
helpful to her.
Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 1/19/2024. She reported
being one of two staff supervising the youth on the outing in which
Youth B went AWOL. The reason the staff were not on the ice
during the skate was because Staff 6 had no skates that were her
size and Staff 5 had nerve damage in her leg that kept her from
skating. She also reported both staff were standing next to the rink
and just on the other side of the Plexiglass, so they were able to
view the youth on the ice. When the buzzer went off ending the
free skate, Youth B disappeared into the crowd. Staff 5 denied
they took their eyes of the youth during the outing. She also gave
the same report outlined in the Incident Report. She gave a similar
report about use of personal cell phones are not to be used in the
milieu and if staff need to communicate, they should step into the
office. She also reported using a cell phone the day of the incident
at the skating rink to inform the facility of what had occurred. She
reported knowing that Youth F is on one-to-one supervision. She
also reported Youth F was scheduled to attend the outing but
because there were only two staff available to supervise, Youth F
was not allowed to go because they would not have been able to
maintain the one-to-one with two staff and five youth.
6

MDHHS Supervisor and MDHHS worker were interviewed via
phone on 1/19/2024. Both reported never requesting a one-to-
one supervision of Youth A. They also reported Youth A continues
to be placed at the facility because there is no appropriate
placement available within the State of Michigan at this time.
Staff 6 was interviewed via phone on 1/25/2024. She reported
being one of two staff supervising the youth on the outing in which
Youth B went AWOL. She provided the same report about the
incident as Staff 5 and what was written in the incident report.
Staff 6 reported the skating rink had no skates that fit her, so she
was unable to go on the ice with the youth but both staff kept their
eyes on the youth while the youth skated. At first, they stood near
the exit door but had a clear view of the rink before moving to the
seats the hockey players use. Both Staff 5 and Staff 6 were able
to view the entire rink the whole time. Youth B disappeared in the
crowd at the end when everyone was leaving the rink at the end of
skating. Staff 6 reported staff have been told not to use their
personal cell phones during work hours and are to place their
phones in the office when in the building. She also reported
checking for messages prior to the beginning of her shift. This
practice began several months ago and presented during team
meetings. Staff 6 reported Youth F is on one-to-one supervision
but not all the time. She also reported the one-to-one supervision
occurs when Youth F is off campus and struggles as outlined in
the request. Staff 6 also reported the facility has enough staff at
this time and there is no staff shortages.
Youth F was interviewed via phone on 1/25/2024. Youth F
reported no concerns and feeling safe at the facility. Youth F also
reported the program is helping her make changes and staff are
very helpful. Staff support Youth F and provide one-to-one
supervision at times especially when she needs the support.
Documents Reviewed:
Incident Report 170870214 dated 12/31/2023 for Youth B. This
report outlines Youth B going AWOL during an off-campus activity.
The incident occurred at a local indoor ice-skating rink. Staff 5 and
Staff 6 observed Youth B skating and supervised her throughout
the skating time. When leaving, there was a large crowd of
individuals leaving the rink and this is when Staff 5 and Staff 6 lost
sight of Youth B in the crowd. Staff 5 and Staff 6 began to ask
other youth if anyone observed Youth B and Staff 6 was told by
one of the youth (could not identify which) that Youth B was sitting
outside of the rink area on a bench tying her skates. When Staff 6
7

reached the bench, Youth B was not present. Staff 5 stayed with
Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E while Staff 6 did a diligent search
of the building before moving outside of the building. Staff 6
searched the immediate area but was unable to locate Youth B.
Staff 6 asked several individuals in the area and gave a
description of Youth B, but all reported not observing Youth A.
Staff 5 and Staff 6 again looked around and sought out possible
video of the area and found they could not access the video.
Finally, staff called the facility to report a suspected AWOL and
had Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E enter the van for transport
back. While Staff 6 stayed with the youth in the van, Staff 5 did
another sweep of the building being allowed into different rooms
by management. Staff 5 also did a sweep of a larger outside area
for about 10 to 15 minutes before giving up and taking Youth C,
Youth D, and Youth E back to the facility.
Wedgewood Christian Services Activity Treatment
Residential Staff Expectations dated 8/31/18. This document
outlies the expectation of staff when supervising youth on an
activity. Staff are to make certain there are no unsupervised
interactions between youth and to monitor physical and emotional
safety during all activities.
Wedgwood Christian Services Dept: Cook Claus Meeting
minutes 11/22/23. This document outlines the need to limit cell
phone use to only as needed. Cell phone use in the milieu is to be
specifically for emergencies or work related.
Wedgwood Christian Services Dept: Cook Claus Meeting
minutes 12/8/23. This document outlines that staff are to leave
their cell phones in the office, their box, or their bag while on the
unit. The only exception to this change is that the shift supervisor,
school staff (while in the classroom) and when staff are off
grounds may have the use of their cell phone.
Email from Administrator 2 to the Cook Claus team dated
12/18/23. This document notes staff are not to text or call their co-
workers since staff are not to have their cell phone to receive the
message or call. Shift supervisors and staff that go off grounds are
to put their phone away when they return to the facility.
Wedgwood Christian Services Dept: Cook Claus Meeting
minutes ¼/24. This document outlines the staffing meeting in
which staff are reminded about cell phone usage. It is documented
cell phones are to be kept in the office. Staff will receive
8

disciplinary action in the form of a write up if cell phones are
misused.
Informational note 12/21/23 on Youth A. This note documents
the meeting between Administrator 1 and MDHHS Supervisor and
MDHHS Case Worker. This document outlines that staff are not to
meet with Youth A in a one-to-one setting due to Youth A making
several allegations against staff and other youth.
Updated Safety Plan for Youth A dated 9/5/23. This document
outlines the actions staff are to take to ensure Youth A’s safety
which include one-to-one supervision when Youth A is in the
milieu with other youth. Youth A is to be housed in the short
hallway and no other youth are permitted to use this bedroom or
bathroom while this safety plan is in place.
Updated Safety Plan for Youth A dated 9/15/23. This document
outlines the actions staff are to take to ensure Youth A’s safety
which include one-to-one supervision when Youth A is in the
milieu with other youth. During mealtime and milieu activities
Youth A is to sit next to staff and be within arm’s length when in
the hallway where other youth are present.
Updated Safety Plan for Youth A dated 9/26/23. Youth A will no
longer be provided one-to-one supervision when in the hallway or
bathrooms. Youth A is allowed to participate in off campus
activities when staff can be within arm’s length. Youth A is still to
sit next to staff at mealtimes.
Updated Safety Plan for Youth A dated 12/18/23. This
document outlines the following staff requirements with Youth A.
Youth A is not to be left unattended with other youth in secluded
areas of the campus. Youth A is to have limited interactions with
the youth that engaged in the assault of Youth A. Youth A will not
display any sexual behaviors and speak to the therapist if
experiencing these feelings.
One-to-one Weekly Tracking Sheet for Youth F with approved
1:1 supervision up to 16 hours per day. This log covers
1/3/2024 to 1/8/2024 and provides Youth F’s actions during the
one-to-one supervision period. One day has no documentation of
one-to-one supervision and the other five days document 5 hours
per day for four of the days and 11 hours of one-to-one
supervision for one of the days.
9

Staffing schedule November 12, 2024 to January 11, 2024.
This document outlines the staff present for each day and the time
during that day the staff were working with youth. There is no gaps
or lack of staffing identified in this document. Several shifts
overlap and with the exception of the overnight shift, there are
three to four staff present throughout the day and evening.
Request for 1:1 supervision. Documentation outlines the
facility sought 1:1 supervision for Youth F on 11/8/2023.
Approval for the one-to-one supervision was verbally provided on
11/30/23 and final approval given on 12/21/23. The requested
one-to-one supervision was approved for the period of 11/8/23 to
2/23/24. Rational for this level of supervision was given as Youth
F continues to present with self-harming behaviors (superficial
injuries), stealing, lying about conflicts she has begun, and limited
progress. The facility requested to have the one-to-one
supervision for only 16 hours per day and then only “after school,
weekends”, and when it appears Youth F needed additional
emotional support. The overall focus will be to provide the clinical
support for Youth F that she needs to continually address her
mental and emotional health needs.
Billing invoice for 1:1 with Youth F November 2023. During this
month, it is documented one-to-one services were billed starting
on 11/8/23 and running until the end of the month. The number of
hours is less during school days than on the weekends or
holidays. The range of hours per day runs from 5 to 15 hours per
day.
Billing invoice for 1:1 with Youth F December 2023. During this
month, it is documented one-to-one services were billed starting
on 12/1/23 and running until the end of the month. During this
period, Youth F received one-to-one supervision for three
weekend days, and seven weekdays. The range of hours per the
days of one-to-one supervision range from 5 to 16 hours per day.
Human Resources file for Staff 5 was reviewed. Staff 5 was
hired at the facility on 1/27/2023. Training documentation
indicates, Staff 5 is current on the required training. This includes
Crisis Prevention & De escalation completed on 9/14/23,
Communication and Conflict Management skills on 2/10/23, and
Effective Teamwork on 2/24/23.
Human Resources file for Staff 6 was reviewed. Staff 6 was
hired at the facility on 2/21/2023. Training documentation
indicates, Staff 5 is current on the required training. This includes
10

Crisis Prevention & De-escalation on 9/14/23, Communication and
Conflict Management skills on 3/6/23, and Effective Teamwork on
2/24/23.
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation there is no
evidence that supports staff were not providing the appropriate
level of supervision in each of the three allegations. Neither youth
(Youth A and Youth F) identified in the allegations of inappropriate
one-to-one supervision was found to be lacking the supervision
approved by the referring sources and documentation indicates
the staff were providing the appropriate supervision. In regard to
the cell phone use, all staff interviewed reported they are not to
use their cell phones on the milieu and that this practice began
several months ago. This was documented through team meeting
which were reviewed. Ln the AWOL situation it was found staff did
provide the appropriate level of supervision and this was
confirmed by youth at the activity.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
